DOCNAME: CASE OF DEVENNEY v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 14 or 13;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant began work in FAC , GPE , as a silver service waiter . This hotel is owned by ORG , which is subsidiary of ORG . Initially the applicant had been doing very well and was optimistic about promotion . On DATE , the restaurant manager informed the applicant that he was being dismissed forthwith . The applicant was given no reason whatsoever for his peremptory dismissal . Various attempts to get an explanation for the dismissal were unsuccessful . Ultimately the general manager told the applicant on DATE that he was dismissed because he did not meet the grade and there was no other reason . Of all the full - time and permanent staff in the restaurant the applicant believes that he was the only NORP .

CARDINAL . The applicant made a complaint to ORG that he had been unlawfully discriminated against on the grounds of religious belief or political opinion . The applicant and CARDINAL of his CARDINAL siblings are not involved in any politically related activity .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant ’s solicitors wrote to the Chief Constable of ORG ( “ ORG ” ) stating that they had been informed that the reason for the applicant ’s dismissal from his employment at FAC was an approach made to the ORG by members of the ORG who had stated that the applicant was a suspect . The solicitors requested that the ORG provide information as to what the applicant was suspected of and on what basis the applicant had been allegedly described as a suspect . The ORG replied to this letter , stating that they were unable to comment on such matters , it not being force policy to do so .
CARDINAL . On DATE the solicitors acting on behalf of the applicant ’s employers wrote to ORG .

“ We return herewith Notice of Appearance in relation to the application presented by Mr PERSON . On our instructions , the acts of which complaint is made , were done for the purpose of protecting public safety , and in the circumstances by virtue of LAW of LAW DATE , ORG ( GPE ) Acts do not apply so that the tribunal does not have jurisdiction to entertain the complaint . ”
CARDINAL . The Fair Employment Tribunal then of its own motion fixed a preliminary hearing for determination of the following issue :
“ Whether the tribunal has jurisdiction to consider the applicant ’s complaint in view of the provisions of LAW of ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , acting on behalf of the applicant , wrote to the solicitors acting on behalf of the applicant ’s employers requesting to know , inter alia , whether the Secretary of ORG or any other ORG had been approached with a view to obtaining a LAW ( CARDINAL ) certificate . By reply of DATE the ORG solicitors stated :

“ We DATE received your letter dated DATE in relation to the above . You will be pleased to hear that during the writer ’s holiday DATE a LAW certificate was received from the ORG office ( a certified copy of which is enclosed herewith ) so that it now seems unnecessary to take any further action , and that you may close your file in this matter . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant stated that he did not know the basis upon which the certificate was issued . He had never been shown , and was not entitled to demand , sight of the information , if any , which was placed before the Secretary of ORG which led to the certificate being issued . The applicant did not know whether this information was correct or incorrect , whether it was complete or incomplete , and whether it was reliable or not . Nor did he know whether the information provided could reasonably support the view expressed in the certificate .

CARDINAL . The matter first came before ORG on DATE . On that occasion the ORG declared that the certificate presented did not affect the applicability of LAW to the dismissal of the applicant by ORG , since the certificate referred to an act done by ORG .

CARDINAL . At a resumed hearing on DATE ORG were presented with a new certificate signed by the Secretary of ORG for GPE and certifying that the decision by ORG to terminate its contract of employment with the applicant was for the purpose of protecting public safety and public order . In light of the certificate , ORG found that LAW did not apply to the termination of the applicant ’s contract , nor to the decision summarily to terminate the contract and accordingly that :
“ there is nothing for this ORG to consider in relation to that act [ of termination ] . ”
The tribunal dismissed the applicant ’s complaints in relation to his dismissal and the manner of his dismissal .

CARDINAL . By virtue of LAW of ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE ( “ the LAW ” ) it is unlawful for an employer to discriminate against a person on grounds of religious belief or political opinion in relation to employment in GPE , inter alia , by dismissing him or subjecting him to any other detriment . By virtue of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act as amended , a complaint of unlawful discrimination may be presented to ORG , which is established by statute to investigate complaints of unlawful discrimination on grounds of religious belief or political opinion .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act provides as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The Fair Employment ( GPE ) Acts shall not apply to an act done for the purpose of safeguarding national security or protecting public safety or public order .

( CARDINAL ) A certificate signed by , or on behalf of the Secretary of ORG and certifying that an act specified in the certificate was done for the purpose mentioned in sub - section ( CARDINAL ) shall be conclusive evidence that it was done for that purpose .

( CARDINAL ) A document purporting to be a document such as is mentioned in subsection ( CARDINAL ) shall be received in evidence and , unless the contrary is proved , shall be deemed to be such a certificate . ”
